title: Supplemental Notes
text: Additional resources and extended topics that complement the main course material.

title: Supplemental Notes
text:
Advanced Topics
These optional materials dive deeper into specialized areas of data visualization:

1. Advanced Color Theory

Color spaces and perceptual uniformity
Advanced accessibility considerations
Cultural color associations



2. Statistical Visualization

Uncertainty visualization
Bayesian visualization
High-dimensional data techniques



3. Web Technologies

D3.js advanced patterns
Canvas vs SVG performance
WebGL for visualization



4. Visualization Research

Current research trends
Evaluation methodologies
Perception studies

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text: Common issues and solutions for SMM635 computing setup.

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Installation Issues

Python/Anaconda






conda: command not found





Problem: Terminal doesn‚Äôt recognize conda commands
Solutions: 1. Windows: Add Anaconda to PATH - Search ‚ÄúEnvironment Variables‚Äù in Start Menu - Add C:\Users\YourName\Anaconda3\Scripts to PATH - Restart terminal

Mac/Linux: Source conda
source ~/anaconda3/bin/activate
conda init
Alternative: Use Anaconda Prompt (Windows) or full path










Package conflicts during installation





Problem: ‚ÄúSolving environment‚Äù takes forever or fails
Solutions: 1. Create fresh environment: bash    conda create -n smm635_fresh python=3.9    conda activate smm635_fresh    conda install matplotlib seaborn plotly

Use mamba (faster solver):
conda install -n base mamba
mamba install package_name
Use pip for specific packages:
pip install plotly --upgrade






R/RStudio






‚ÄúPackage not available for R version‚Äù





Problem: Can‚Äôt install certain packages
Solutions: 1. Update R to latest version 2. Install from source: r    install.packages("package_name", type = "source") 3. Use development version: r    devtools::install_github("author/package")









RStudio won‚Äôt start





Problem: RStudio crashes or shows blank screen
Solutions: 1. Reset RStudio state: - Mac: rm -rf ~/.rstudio-desktop - Windows: Delete %localappdata%\RStudio-Desktop

Update graphics drivers
Try RStudio Cloud as temporary solution

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Runtime Errors

Python






ModuleNotFoundError





Problem: Python can‚Äôt find installed package
Solutions: 1. Check you‚Äôre in correct environment: bash    conda activate smm635    conda list  # Should show your packages

Reinstall package:
conda install package_name -c conda-forge
Check Jupyter kernel:
python -m ipykernel install --user --name smm635










Matplotlib figures not showing





Problem: Plots don‚Äôt appear in notebook
Solutions: 1. Add magic command: python    %matplotlib inline

For interactive plots:
%matplotlib widget
Explicitly show plots:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.show()






R






‚Äúcould not find function‚Äù





Problem: R doesn‚Äôt recognize function
Solutions: 1. Load the library: r    library(ggplot2)  # or appropriate package

Use full namespace:
ggplot2::ggplot(...)
Check spelling and case sensitivity










ggplot shows blank plot





Problem: No output from ggplot
Solutions: 1. Assign and print: r    p <- ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) + geom_point()    print(p)

Check data isn‚Äôt empty:
nrow(data)  # Should be > 0

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Performance Issues






Slow plotting with large datasets





Solutions: 1. Sample data: python    df_sample = df.sample(n=10000)

Use datashader for millions of points:
import datashader as ds
Aggregate before plotting:
df_summary <- df %>%
  group_by(category) %>%
  summarize(mean_value = mean(value))










Jupyter notebook keeps crashing





Solutions: 1. Increase memory limit: python    import resource    resource.setrlimit(resource.RLIMIT_AS, (2147483648, 2147483648))

Clear output regularly:

Cell ‚Üí All Output ‚Üí Clear

Use .py scripts for heavy processing

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Git/GitHub Issues






Permission denied (publickey)





Problem: Can‚Äôt push to GitHub
Solutions: 1. Use HTTPS instead of SSH: bash    git remote set-url origin https://github.com/user/repo.git

Set up SSH key:
ssh-keygen -t ed25519
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
# Copy and add to GitHub settings
Use GitHub Desktop or VS Code git integration










Large files rejected





Problem: GitHub won‚Äôt accept files > 100MB
Solutions: 1. Use .gitignore: *.csv    data/    *.pkl

Use Git LFS:
git lfs track "*.csv"
git add .gitattributes
Store data externally (Google Drive, Dropbox)

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Quick Fixes

Reset Everything
If all else fails, here‚Äôs how to start fresh:
# Backup your work first!

# Remove conda environment
conda env remove -n smm635

# Clear conda cache
conda clean --all

# Reinstall from scratch
conda env create -f smm635.yaml


Emergency Alternatives
When you need to work RIGHT NOW:

Google Colab: No setup needed
!pip install plotly seaborn
Binder: Share environment

Add requirements.txt to repo
Visit mybinder.org

University computers: Usually have everything installed

title: Troubleshooting Guide
text:
Getting More Help
If these solutions don‚Äôt work:

Document the problem:

Exact error message
What you were trying to do
Your operating system
Screenshot if helpful

Search first:

Google the exact error
Check Stack Overflow
Search course forum

Ask for help:

Post on course forum
Come to office hours
Email TA with details








Remember



Most problems have been solved before! Don‚Äôt spend hours struggling alone - ask for help after 30 minutes of troubleshooting.

title: Welcome to SMM635!
text: SMM635 Data Visualization is a comprehensive introduction to the principles and practice of data visualization. This module combines theoretical foundations with hands-on experience using industry-standard tools and programming languages. Students will learn to create effective, ethical, and aesthetically pleasing visualizations that communicate complex data insights to diverse audiences.

title: Welcome to SMM635!
text:
Course overview
Data visualization is the art and science of transforming data into visual representations that effectively communicate insights, patterns, and stories. In this module, you will:

Create static and interactive visualizations
Work with different data types: statistical estimates, temporal, spatial, network, and text data
Develop skills in exploratory data analysis
Build compelling data stories
Design and execute dashboards

title: Welcome to SMM635!
text:
Key information


Lecture
Thursday, 11:00 AM - 12:50 PM
Room FSQ510
Lab
Thursday, 3:00 PM - 4:50 PM
Room FSQ407


Instructors
Simone Santoni
Yinji (Benedict) Zhou
Office hours: By appointment

title: Welcome to SMM635!
text:
Learning objectives
By the end of this module, you will be able to:

Design effective visualizations following perceptual and aesthetic principles
Create publication-quality static visualizations using Python and R
Critique visualizations based on established design principles
Communicate data insights through visual storytelling

title: Welcome to SMM635!
text:
Course materials
All course materials, including lecture slides, lab notebooks, and datasets, will be posted on this website. We will primarily use:

R (ggplot2, plotly, shiny)
Python (matplotlib, seaborn, plotly, Vega-Altair)
Tableau (for rapid prototyping)

title: Welcome to SMM635!
text:
Prerequisites

Basic programming skills in Python or R
Understanding of basic statistics
No prior visualization experience required!

title: Welcome to SMM635!
text:
Getting help
Check out the Support page for information on getting help with course content, computing issues, or other concerns.

title: Week 1: Introduction to Data Visualization
text: This week we‚Äôll explore what data visualization is, why it matters, and set up our development environment. We‚Äôll create our first visualizations and discuss the course structure.

title: Week 1: Introduction to Data Visualization
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Explain the importance and applications of data visualization
Set up a data visualization development environment
Create basic plots using matplotlib and ggplot2
Identify different types of data and appropriate visualizations
Navigate course resources and tools

title: Week 1: Introduction to Data Visualization
text:
Looking Ahead
Next week we‚Äôll dive into visual perception and design principles. Start thinking about visualizations you encounter in your daily life: - What makes them effective or ineffective? - How do they use color, shape, and position? - What story are they trying to tell?







Pro Tip



Start a visualization journal! Screenshot or save interesting visualizations you find online or in print. We‚Äôll analyze these throughout the course.








Important Dates

Office Hours: Tuesday, 4:00-5:00 PM

text: Learning data visualization involves both creative design thinking and technical implementation. We‚Äôre here to support you throughout your learning journey!

title: Support
text:
Common Issues and Solutions

Installation Problems






Can‚Äôt install Python packages?



Try using conda instead of pip:
conda install -c conda-forge matplotlib seaborn plotly








R package installation fails?



Check you have the latest R version and try:
install.packages("tidyverse", dependencies = TRUE)




Coding Challenges






General debugging steps




Read the error message carefully
Google the exact error message
Check the documentation
Create a minimal reproducible example
Post on the course forum with your example





Visualization Design






Not sure which chart type to use?




Visit From Data to Viz
Identify your data type
Follow the decision tree
Review examples in the gallery

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Basic programming knowledge in either Python or R is required. You should be comfortable with: - Variables and data types - Control structures (if/else, loops) - Functions - Basic data manipulation
If you‚Äôre rusty, we recommend completing a refresher tutorial before the course starts.



Yes! While we teach both languages to give you flexibility, you can complete all assignments in your preferred language. The final project can mix languages if desired.



This course emphasizes both design principles and technical implementation. While we welcome students from design backgrounds, you‚Äôll need basic programming skills to succeed. Consider taking an introductory programming course first.



Plan for approximately 10 hours per week: - 2 hours lectures - 2 hours labs
- 6 hours self-study, assignments, and projects

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Basic programming knowledge in either Python or R is required. You should be comfortable with: - Variables and data types - Control structures (if/else, loops) - Functions - Basic data manipulation
If you‚Äôre rusty, we recommend completing a refresher tutorial before the course starts.



Yes! While we teach both languages to give you flexibility, you can complete all assignments in your preferred language. The final project can mix languages if desired.



This course emphasizes both design principles and technical implementation. While we welcome students from design backgrounds, you‚Äôll need basic programming skills to succeed. Consider taking an introductory programming course first.



Plan for approximately 10 hours per week: - 2 hours lectures - 2 hours labs
- 6 hours self-study, assignments, and projects

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Technical Questions

What computer specifications do I need?

Minimum: 8GB RAM, 256GB storage, any OS
Recommended: 16GB RAM, 512GB storage, dedicated graphics card
Lab computers are available if your laptop doesn‚Äôt meet requirements



Can I use my tablet/iPad?
Tablets are great for reading and sketching, but you‚Äôll need a laptop or desktop for coding assignments. Cloud-based options like Google Colab can work in a pinch.


Which IDE should I use?
We recommend: - Python: VS Code or JupyterLab - R: RStudio - Both: VS Code with appropriate extensions
Choose what you‚Äôre comfortable with!


Do I need to install everything before the first class?
No, we‚Äôll have an installation party during the first lab. However, attempting installation beforehand helps identify issues early.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Assignment Questions

Can I submit assignments late?
Late submissions incur a 10% penalty per day. After 5 days, assignments won‚Äôt be accepted. See syllabus for emergency extension policy.


How are group projects graded?
Group projects receive a base grade, with individual adjustments based on: - Peer evaluations - Individual contribution statements - Git commit history


Can I use code from the internet?
Yes, with proper attribution! You must: - Cite all sources - Understand any code you use - Adapt it to your specific needs - Never copy entire solutions


What constitutes plagiarism in visualization?

Copying code without attribution
Reproducing others‚Äô visualizations without credit
Submitting others‚Äô work as your own
Using generative AI without disclosure

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Project Questions

Can I use my work/research data for projects?
Absolutely! Real-world data makes projects more meaningful. Ensure: - You have permission to use the data - No confidential information is included - Data is appropriately anonymized - You can share it with classmates for peer review


What makes a good final project?
Strong final projects typically: - Tell a compelling data story - Use appropriate visualization techniques - Include interactive elements - Show technical proficiency - Demonstrate design principles - Are well-documented


Can I continue working on my project after the course?
Yes! Many students develop their projects into: - Portfolio pieces - Research publications - Open-source contributions - Startup ideas

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Career Questions

What careers use data visualization?

Data Scientist/Analyst
Business Intelligence Developer
UX/UI Designer
Data Journalist
Research Scientist
Product Manager
Consultant



Should I specialize in one tool or learn many?
We recommend: 1. Master one language deeply (Python or R) 2. Understand multiple tools‚Äô capabilities 3. Learn underlying principles that transfer 4. Stay curious about new developments


How do I build a visualization portfolio?

Complete all course projects thoughtfully
Contribute to open-source projects
Participate in visualization challenges
Create personal projects with interesting data
Document your process, not just results

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text:
Practical Matters

Is lecture attendance mandatory?
Lectures aren‚Äôt mandatory but strongly encouraged. We don‚Äôt record lectures to encourage participation and discussion. Slides are posted after class.


Can I audit the course?
Contact the instructor to discuss auditing options. Auditors are welcome in lectures but may have limited access to labs and computing resources.


Are there prerequisites I should review?
Review these topics before the course: - Basic statistics (mean, median, distributions) - Data manipulation (filtering, grouping, joining) - File I/O in your chosen language


How do I get help if I‚Äôm struggling?

Attend office hours early and often
Form study groups
Post on the course forum
Visit TA hours
Reach out to the instructor

Don‚Äôt wait until you‚Äôre behind!







Didn‚Äôt find your question?



Post it on the course forum or ask during office hours. We‚Äôll add common questions to this FAQ throughout the term.


Remember: There are no stupid questions! If you‚Äôre wondering about something, others probably are too.

title: Access Computing Resources
text: This guide will help you set up all the software needed for SMM635. All tools are free and open-source.

title: Access Computing Resources
text:
Quick Start






Installation Party



We‚Äôll have a dedicated session in Week 1 Lab to help everyone get set up. Don‚Äôt worry if you run into issues!

title: Access Computing Resources
text:
Required Software

1. Python Environment
We recommend using Anaconda, which includes Python and essential data science packages.

Installation Steps

Download Anaconda

Visit anaconda.com/download
Choose Python 3.9+ version for your operating system
Download the installer (graphical installer recommended)

Install Anaconda

Run the installer
Accept default settings
Important: Add Anaconda to your PATH (Windows users)

Create Course Environment
# Download the environment file from course repo
curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/simoneSantoni/data-viz-smm635/main/resources/smm635.yaml

# Create the environment
conda env create -f smm635.yaml

# Activate the environment
conda activate smm635
Verify Installation
python --version  # Should show Python 3.9+
jupyter --version # Should show jupyter installation




2. R and RStudio

Installation Steps

Install R

Visit r-project.org
Choose your CRAN mirror
Download R 4.0+ for your operating system

Install RStudio

Visit posit.co/downloads
Download RStudio Desktop (free version)
Install following default settings

Install Required Packages
# Run in RStudio console
install.packages(c(
  "tidyverse",
  "plotly", 
  "shiny",
  "gganimate",
  "RColorBrewer",
  "viridis",
  "patchwork",
  "here"
))




3. Visual Studio Code (Optional but Recommended)
VS Code is a powerful editor that works well with both Python and R.

Download VS Code

Visit code.visualstudio.com
Download for your operating system

Install Extensions

Python
R
Jupyter
Rainbow CSV
Live Share (for collaboration)




4. Git and GitHub
Version control is essential for tracking your work and collaborating.

Install Git

Visit git-scm.com
Download and install
Configure with your information:

git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"
Create GitHub Account

Visit github.com
Sign up for free account
Consider applying for GitHub Student Pack

Set up SSH Key (Optional)
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.email@example.com"
# Follow prompts, then add to GitHub settings

title: Access Computing Resources
text:
Platform-Specific Instructions

WindowsmacOSLinux


Additional Tools - Install Windows Terminal for better command line experience - Consider WSL2 for Linux environment
Common Issues - If conda commands don‚Äôt work, add to PATH manually - Disable antivirus temporarily during installation - Run installers as administrator


Prerequisites - Install Xcode Command Line Tools: bash   xcode-select --install
Homebrew (Optional) - Install Homebrew for easier package management - Then use: brew install git r
Common Issues - Grant terminal permissions in Security settings - M1 Macs: Some packages may need Rosetta 2


Package Managers - Ubuntu/Debian: apt-get - Fedora: dnf - Arch: pacman
Example (Ubuntu)
sudo apt update
sudo apt install python3-pip git r-base
Common Issues - May need to install additional system libraries - Check your distribution‚Äôs documentation

title: Syllabus
text: Click here to download a copy of the syllabus.

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Description
SMM635 Data Visualization is a comprehensive introduction to the principles and practice of data visualization. This module combines theoretical foundations with hands-on experience using industry-standard tools and programming languages. Students will learn to create effective, ethical, and aesthetically pleasing visualizations that communicate complex data insights to diverse audiences.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Outcomes
Upon successful completion of this module, students will be able to:

Analyze the effectiveness of data visualizations using principles of visual perception and design
Design appropriate visualizations for different data types and communication objectives
Implement static and interactive visualizations using Python, R, and web technologies
Evaluate the ethical implications of design choices in data visualization
Create comprehensive data stories that effectively communicate insights

title: Syllabus
text:
Module Structure
The module runs for 10 weeks with the following components:

Lectures (2 hours/week): Theory, principles, and case studies
Labs (2 hours/week): Hands-on coding and visualization practice
Self-study (6 hours/week): Readings, tutorials, and assignments

title: Syllabus
text:
Required Software
All software used in this module is free and open-source:

Python 3.8+ with Anaconda distribution
R 4.0+ with RStudio
Visual Studio Code or Jupyter Lab
Git and GitHub account
Tableau Public (optional)

See the Computing Resources page for installation instructions.

title: Syllabus
text:
Textbooks and Resources

Required Reading

Cairo, A. (2016). The Truthful Art. New Riders.
Wilke, C. (2019). Fundamentals of Data Visualization. O‚ÄôReilly. Free online



Recommended Reading

Tufte, E. (2001). The Visual Display of Quantitative Information. Graphics Press.
Munzner, T. (2014). Visualization Analysis and Design. CRC Press.
Kirk, A. (2019). Data Visualisation: A Handbook for Data Driven Design. Sage.

Data Visualization Society

title: Syllabus
text:
Course Policies

Attendance
While lectures are not mandatory, regular attendance is strongly encouraged. Lab sessions include peer activities that cannot be made up.


Late Submission

10% penalty per day for late submissions
Assignments more than 5 days late will not be accepted
Extensions may be granted for documented emergencies



Academic Integrity
All submitted work must be your own. You may discuss concepts with classmates, but code and visualizations must be created independently. Proper attribution is required for all external resources.


Collaboration Policy

Lab assignments: Individual work, discussion encouraged
Midterm project: Individual work only
Final project: Group work with individual contributions clearly identified

title: Syllabus
text:
Communication
This website provides students with access to any course materials.
Moodle messages and forum. Email to discuss sensitive matters.

title: Syllabus
text:
Diversity and Inclusion
This module values diversity and seeks to create an inclusive learning environment. If you have any concerns or suggestions for improving the classroom climate, please don‚Äôt hesitate to speak with me.

title: Syllabus
text:
Accommodations
Students with documented disabilities who may need accommodations should make an appointment with me as soon as possible. All discussions will remain confidential.

title: Syllabus
text:
Changes to Syllabus
This syllabus may be revised during the term. Any changes will be announced in class and posted on the course website.

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
What makes a good dataset for visualization? - Multiple variables (quantitative and categorical) - Temporal or spatial components - Sufficient observations for meaningful patterns - Clean enough to use, messy enough to be interesting - Tells a story you care about
Where to find datasets: - See our data sources list - Your own research or work (with permission) - APIs from services you use - Web scraping (check robots.txt) - Government open data portals



Always start with exploratory data analysis:
# Quick data overview
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('your_data.csv')
print(df.info())
print(df.describe())
print(df.head())

# Check for missing values
print(df.isnull().sum())

# Quick visualizations
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
df.hist(figsize=(12, 8))
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()









Paper First!



Sketch at least 5 different visualization approaches on paper before coding. This helps you: - Think through the story - Identify required data transformations
- Plan interactive elements - Save time overall

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:

Always start with exploratory data analysis:
# Quick data overview
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('your_data.csv')
print(df.info())

# Quick visualizations

Paper First!

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Design Best Practices

Color Selection

Start with grayscale - Ensure it works without color
Use color purposefully - Highlight, group, or encode
Check accessibility - Use colorblind-safe palettes
Be consistent - Same color = same meaning



Typography

Hierarchy: Use size and weight to guide the eye
Readability: Sans-serif for screens, adequate size
Consistency: Maximum 2 font families
Labels: Direct labeling > legends when possible



Layout Principles

Visual hierarchy: Most important elements prominent
White space: Let visualizations breathe
Alignment: Create clean sight lines
Balance: Distribute visual weight evenly

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Technical Tips

Performance Optimization
For large datasets:
# Sampling for development
df_dev = df.sample(n=10000, random_state=42)

# Aggregation before plotting
df_agg = df.groupby('category').agg({
    'value': ['mean', 'std', 'count']
}).reset_index()

# Use efficient libraries
import datashader as ds  # For millions of points
import vaex  # For out-of-core computation


Interactive Features
Start simple, add complexity: 1. Hover tooltips - Show details on demand 2. Filtering - Let users focus on subsets 3. Zooming/panning - Explore dense regions 4. Linked views - Coordinate multiple charts 5. Animations - Show change over time


Deployment Options
For sharing your work: - Static: GitHub Pages, Netlify - Python apps: Streamlit, Dash, Heroku - R apps: Shiny, shinyapps.io - Notebooks: Binder, Google Colab - Dashboards: Tableau Public, Observable

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Project Management

Version Control
# Initialize git repository
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial project setup"

# Create .gitignore
echo "data/large_file.csv" >> .gitignore
echo "*.pyc" >> .gitignore
echo ".DS_Store" >> .gitignore


Project Structure
my_project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md           # Project description
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ data/              
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/           # Original data
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ processed/     # Cleaned data
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ notebooks/         # Exploration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/              # Source code
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ visuals/          # Output images
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/             # Documentation
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ requirements.txt   # Dependencies


Documentation Template
Your README should include: 1. Project title and description 2. Data source and collection method 3. Key findings/insights 4. Technical requirements 5. How to run the code 6. Future improvements

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Design Mistakes

üö´ Too many colors
üö´ 3D charts for 2D data

üö´ Truncated y-axes
üö´ Overcrowded layouts
üö´ Decoration over function



Technical Mistakes

üö´ Not handling missing data
üö´ Hardcoded values
üö´ No error handling
üö´ Poor performance with large data
üö´ Not testing edge cases



Process Mistakes

üö´ Starting coding too early
üö´ Not iterating on designs
üö´ Ignoring user feedback
üö´ Last-minute deployment
üö´ Poor time management

text:

title: Project Tips & Resources
text:
Final Checklist
Before submission: - [ ] Code runs without errors - [ ] Documentation is complete - [ ] Visualizations are accessible - [ ] Story is clear and compelling - [ ] All sources are cited - [ ] Tested on different devices - [ ] Peer feedback incorporated - [ ] Repository is clean and organized






Remember



The best visualizations are rarely the first attempt. Iterate, get feedback, and refine!


Need help? Visit office hours or post on the course forum!

title: Project Instructions
text:
The course includes two main projects that allow you to apply data visualization principles to real-world data:

Midterm Project (Week 6) - Individual static visualization project
Final Project (Week 11) - Group interactive visualization project

title: Project Instructions
text:
The course includes two main projects that allow you to apply data visualization principles to real-world data:

Midterm Project (Week 6) - Individual static visualization project
Final Project (Week 11) - Group interactive visualization project

title: Project Instructions
text:
Midterm Project (30%)

Objectives
Create a comprehensive static visualization report that demonstrates your understanding of design principles and technical skills.


Requirements

Use a dataset of your choice (minimum 1000 observations)
Create at least 5 different visualization types
Apply appropriate color schemes and typography
Include written analysis and design justifications
Submit as a PDF report (8-10 pages)



Deliverables

Project proposal (Week 3)
Data exploration notebook
Final visualization report
Code repository

title: Project Instructions
text:
Final Project (40%)

Objectives
Work in teams to create an interactive dashboard or data story that provides insights into a complex dataset.


Requirements

Teams of 2-3 students
Interactive elements (filters, hover, zoom)
Multiple coordinated views
Responsive design
Clear narrative structure



Deliverables

Project proposal (Week 7)
Design mockups
Interactive visualization (deployed)
Technical documentation
Team presentation (Week 10)

title: Project Instructions
text:
Project Guidelines

Choosing a Dataset

Publicly available data
Sufficient complexity for analysis
Ethical considerations addressed
Novel insights possible



Evaluation Criteria

Design (30%): Aesthetics, clarity, appropriateness
Technical (30%): Code quality, functionality, performance
Analysis (25%): Insights, storytelling, accuracy
Documentation (15%): Clarity, completeness, reproducibility

title: Project Instructions
text:
Timeline

Midterm Project

Week 3: Proposal due
Week 4: Feedback on proposals
Week 5: Check-in during office hours
Week 6: Final submission



Final Project

Week 7: Team formation and proposals
Week 8: Design review
Week 9: Implementation support
Week 10: Presentations
Week 11: Final submission

title: Project Instructions
text:
Resources

Example projects from previous years
Dataset suggestions

Presentation templates







Start Early!



Good visualizations require iteration. Begin exploring data and sketching ideas as soon as possible.


Questions? See Project Tips or visit office hours.

title: Week 2: Visual Perception & Design Principles
text: This week we‚Äôll explore how humans perceive visual information and apply design principles to create effective visualizations. We‚Äôll learn about color theory, cognitive load, and accessibility.

title: Week 2: Visual Perception & Design Principles
text: This week we‚Äôll explore how humans perceive visual information and apply design principles to create effective visualizations. We‚Äôll learn about color theory, cognitive load, and accessibility.

title: Week 2: Visual Perception & Design Principles
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Understand how the human visual system processes information
Apply pre-attentive attributes in visualization design
Use color effectively and accessibly
Reduce cognitive load through good design
Create visualizations that follow design principles

title: Week 2: Visual Perception & Design Principles
text:
Lecture Slides
üìä Visual Perception & Design

text:

Required

Cairo, A. (2016). The Truthful Art, Chapter 6: ‚ÄúThe Eye and the Visual Brain‚Äù

text:

Lab 2

Applying Design Principles
In this lab, you will: - Redesign poorly designed visualizations - Apply color theory principles - Test accessibility compliance - Create visualization critiques - Practice with different chart types

title: Week 2: Visual Perception & Design Principles
text:
Looking Ahead
Next week we‚Äôll focus on choosing the right chart type for your data and message. Start noticing: - How different publications use color - Which visualizations are easy vs.¬†difficult to read - How color affects your interpretation of data







Pro Tip



Use your phone‚Äôs accessibility settings to test how your visualizations look with different vision types. Most phones have built-in color blindness simulators.

title: Week 7: Data Ethics & Responsible Visualization
text: This week we‚Äôll examine the ethical dimensions of data visualization, including bias, misleading representations, privacy concerns, and our responsibilities as data storytellers. We‚Äôll learn to create honest and inclusive visualizations.

title: Week 7: Data Ethics & Responsible Visualization
text: This week we‚Äôll examine the ethical dimensions of data visualization, including bias, misleading representations, privacy concerns, and our responsibilities as data storytellers. We‚Äôll learn to create honest and inclusive visualizations.

title: Week 7: Data Ethics & Responsible Visualization
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Identify common ways visualizations can mislead
Recognize and address bias in data representation
Apply inclusive design principles to visualizations
Consider privacy and consent in data visualization
Create ethical guidelines for your visualization practice

title: Week 7: Data Ethics & Responsible Visualization
text:
Lecture Slides
üìä Data Ethics & Responsible Visualization
Topics covered: - How visualizations can lie or mislead - Cognitive biases and visual perception - Inclusive design and accessibility - Privacy, consent, and data sensitivity - Building ethical visualization practices

title: Week 7: Data Ethics & Responsible Visualization
text:
Readings

Required

Cairo, A. (2019). How Charts Lie, Chapters 1-3
D‚ÄôIgnazio, C. & Klein, L. (2020). Data Feminism, Chapter 6: ‚ÄúThe Numbers Don‚Äôt Speak for Themselves‚Äù



Optional

Seeing Theory - Visual introduction to probability and statistics
Data Visualization Ethics - Tableau guide

title: Week 7: Data Ethics & Responsible Visualization
text:
Lab

Lab 7

Ethical Visualization Audit
In this lab, you will: - Analyze misleading visualizations and identify problems - Redesign problematic charts to be more honest - Create accessibility-compliant visualizations - Develop an ethics checklist for future projects - Present your findings and recommendations
üìò Lab 7 Notebook | Lab 7 Instructions
Due: Friday at 11:59 PM

Pro Tip

title: Week 3: Chart Types & Data Relationships
text: This week we‚Äôll explore different chart types and learn how to match visualization techniques to data types and analytical goals. We‚Äôll cover when to use bar charts, line charts, scatter plots, and more.

title: Week 3: Chart Types & Data Relationships
text: This week we‚Äôll explore different chart types and learn how to match visualization techniques to data types and analytical goals. We‚Äôll cover when to use bar charts, line charts, scatter plots, and more.

title: Week 3: Chart Types & Data Relationships
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Identify different data types and their characteristics
Choose appropriate chart types for different data relationships
Create effective bar charts, line charts, and scatter plots
Understand when to use specialized chart types
Avoid common chart type mistakes

title: Week 3: Chart Types & Data Relationships
text:
Lecture Slides
üìä Chart Types & Data Relationships
Topics covered: - Data types: categorical, ordinal, quantitative - Comparing values: bar charts and alternatives - Showing trends: line charts and time series - Exploring relationships: scatter plots and correlation - Distribution visualization: histograms and box plots

title: Week 3: Chart Types & Data Relationships
text:

Exploring Chart Types

title: Week 3: Chart Types & Data Relationships
text:
Looking Ahead
Next week we‚Äôll dive into interactive visualizations and learn how to add user engagement to our charts. Consider: - Which of this week‚Äôs charts would benefit from interactivity? - What questions might users want to explore? - How could tooltips or filtering enhance understanding?







Pro Tip



Create a personal ‚Äúchart type cheat sheet‚Äù with examples of when to use each type. Include both good and bad examples for reference.








Important Dates

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text: This week students will present their mid-term projects, showcasing the visualization techniques and design principles learned so far. We‚Äôll practice giving and receiving constructive feedback on data visualization work.

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text: This week students will present their mid-term projects, showcasing the visualization techniques and design principles learned so far. We‚Äôll practice giving and receiving constructive feedback on data visualization work.

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Present data visualization projects effectively
Provide constructive feedback on visualization design
Identify strengths and improvement opportunities in peer work
Reflect on your own design process and decisions
Learn from diverse approaches to similar problems

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text:
Presentation Format
üéØ 5-minute presentations followed by 2-minute Q&A
Structure your presentation: 1. Problem/question (30 seconds) 2. Data and approach (1 minute) 3. Design decisions and process (2 minutes) 4. Key insights and findings (1 minute) 5. Reflection and next steps (30 seconds)

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text:
Evaluation Criteria

Technical Implementation (40%)

Appropriate chart types for data and questions
Clean, well-structured code
Proper data handling and processing
Effective use of visualization libraries



Design & Aesthetics (30%)

Clear visual hierarchy and layout
Appropriate use of color and typography
Accessibility considerations
Professional presentation quality



Communication (20%)

Clear problem statement and context
Logical flow and storytelling
Effective annotations and explanations
Engagement with audience questions



Process & Reflection (10%)

Documentation of design decisions
Acknowledgment of limitations
Learning insights and growth
Plans for improvement

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text:
Presentation Schedule
Tuesday Session: - Groups 1-8 present - 15-minute break at midpoint - Peer feedback forms
Thursday Session: - Groups 9-16 present - 15-minute break at midpoint - Course reflection discussion

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text:
Feedback Guidelines

Giving Feedback

Focus on design choices, not personal preferences
Suggest specific improvements
Highlight what works well
Ask clarifying questions about decisions
Be constructive and respectful



Receiving Feedback

Listen actively without defending
Ask follow-up questions for clarity
Take notes for future reference
Thank presenters for their perspectives
Consider feedback in context of your goals

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text:
Resources

Presentation Tips

Designing Effective Presentations
Storytelling with Data Presentations



Peer Review

Constructive Feedback Guidelines
Design Critique Methods

title: Week 8: Student Project Presentations
text:
Looking Ahead
After presentations, we‚Äôll start working on advanced topics and final projects. Consider: - What techniques from peer presentations could you apply? - How might you extend your current project? - What new visualization challenges interest you?







Pro Tip



Practice your presentation timing beforehand. 5 minutes goes by quickly, so focus on your most important points and insights.








Important Dates




Presentations: Tuesday & Thursday this week
Peer Feedback Forms: Due by end of week
Final Project Proposals: Due next week
Office Hours: Available for presentation prep

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text: Our final week! Students will present their completed final projects and we‚Äôll reflect on the course journey. We‚Äôll also discuss next steps for continuing your data visualization learning and practice.

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text: Our final week! Students will present their completed final projects and we‚Äôll reflect on the course journey. We‚Äôll also discuss next steps for continuing your data visualization learning and practice.

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Present a comprehensive data visualization project professionally
Evaluate and provide feedback on complex visualization work
Reflect on your growth throughout the course
Identify areas for continued learning and improvement
Plan your next steps in data visualization

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text:
Final Presentation Format
üéØ 8-minute presentations followed by 3-minute Q&A
Structure your presentation: 1. Problem and context (1 minute) 2. Data and methodology (1.5 minutes) 3. Design process and iterations (2 minutes) 4. Live demonstration (2 minutes) 5. Key insights and impact (1 minute) 6. Reflection and future work (30 seconds)

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text:
Presentation Schedule

Tuesday: Progress Check & Prep

Morning: Individual progress check-ins
Afternoon: Presentation practice sessions
Evening: Final project submission deadline



Thursday: Final Presentations

Session 1: Projects 1-8 (90 minutes)
Break: 30 minutes with refreshments
Session 2: Projects 9-16 (90 minutes)
Wrap-up: Course reflection and celebration

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text:
Evaluation Rubric

Technical Excellence (35%)

Sophisticated Implementation: Advanced techniques used appropriately
Code Quality: Clean, documented, reproducible
Data Handling: Proper preprocessing and validation
Performance: Efficient and responsive



Design & User Experience (35%)

Visual Design: Effective use of design principles
Accessibility: WCAG compliance and inclusive design
Usability: Intuitive interaction and navigation
Innovation: Creative solutions to visualization challenges



Communication & Impact (20%)

Storytelling: Clear narrative and compelling insights
Presentation: Professional delivery and demonstration
Documentation: Comprehensive project documentation
Audience Engagement: Effective Q&A and discussion



Process & Reflection (10%)

Iteration: Evidence of design evolution
Problem-solving: Handling of technical challenges
Learning: Demonstration of skill development
Critical Thinking: Thoughtful evaluation of choices

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text:
Course Reflection

Individual Reflection (Due with Final Project)
Write a 500-word reflection addressing: - What visualization skills have you developed? - Which projects or techniques were most challenging? - How has your understanding of design principles evolved? - What visualization work are you most proud of? - What areas do you want to continue developing?


Group Discussion Topics

Most valuable techniques learned
Biggest challenges overcome
Favorite projects from the course
Advice for future students
Industry trends and opportunities

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text:
Next Steps in Data Visualization

Continued Learning

Advanced Courses: Machine learning visualization, scientific visualization
Conferences: IEEE VIS, EuroVis, Information+
Online Communities: Data Visualization Society, r/dataviz
Books: Advanced texts and specialized topics



Portfolio Development

GitHub Pages: Showcase your projects
Observable: Interactive portfolio pieces
LinkedIn: Professional visualization content
Personal Website: Comprehensive portfolio



Career Paths

Data Analyst/Scientist: Visualization for analysis
UX/UI Designer: Information design and interfaces
Data Journalist: Storytelling with data
Business Intelligence: Dashboard and reporting design
Research Visualization: Academic and scientific visualization

title: Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up
text:
Resources for Continued Growth

Communities

Data Visualization Society
Information is Beautiful
Flowing Data



Tools to Explore

Emerging Platforms: Observable, Figma, Framer
Specialized Tools: Tableau, Power BI, Qlik
Programming Libraries: D3.js, Three.js, Vega-Lite



Datasets for Practice

Kaggle Datasets
Data.gov
Our World in Data








Pro Tip



Keep creating! The best way to maintain and grow your visualization skills is through regular practice and experimentation.








Final Deadlines




Final Projects: Thursday, 11:59 PM
Reflection Essays: Thursday, 11:59 PM
Peer Evaluation Forms: Friday, 11:59 PM









Thank You!



Congratulations on completing SMM635 Data Visualization! It‚Äôs been a pleasure learning and creating with you. Keep visualizing!

title: Week 5: Storytelling with Data
text: This week we‚Äôll learn how to craft compelling narratives with data visualizations. We‚Äôll explore different storytelling structures, annotation techniques, and how to guide audiences through data-driven insights.

title: Week 5: Storytelling with Data
text: This week we‚Äôll learn how to craft compelling narratives with data visualizations. We‚Äôll explore different storytelling structures, annotation techniques, and how to guide audiences through data-driven insights.

title: Week 5: Storytelling with Data
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Structure data stories using narrative frameworks
Create effective annotations and callouts
Design visualizations that guide reader attention
Choose appropriate story types for different contexts
Combine multiple visualizations into cohesive narratives

title: Week 5: Storytelling with Data
text:
Lecture Slides
üìä Storytelling with Data
Topics covered: - Elements of compelling data stories - Narrative structures: explanatory vs.¬†exploratory - Annotation strategies and visual hierarchy - Multi-chart storytelling - Context and framing techniques

title: Week 5: Storytelling with Data
text:
Readings

Required

Knaflic, C. (2015). Storytelling with Data, Chapters 1-2
Segel, E. & Heer, J. (2010). ‚ÄúNarrative Visualization: Telling Stories with Data‚Äù



Optional

The Pudding - Browse visual stories for inspiration
FiveThirtyEight - Data journalism examples

title: Week 5: Storytelling with Data
text:
Lab

Lab 5

Creating Data Stories
In this lab, you will: - Choose a dataset and identify key insights - Create a multi-panel data story - Add effective annotations and callouts - Test your story with different audiences - Present your findings in a compelling format
üìò Lab 5 Notebook | Lab 5 Instructions
Due: Friday at 11:59 PM

title: Week 5: Storytelling with Data
text:
Resources

Tools for Annotation

Matplotlib Annotation Guide
ggplot2 Annotation Functions
Plotly Annotations



Story Examples

New York Times Graphics
Washington Post Graphics
Reuters Graphics



Presentation Tools

Observable Notebooks - Interactive stories
Quarto Presentations - Slides with code

title: Week 5: Storytelling with Data
text:
Looking Ahead
Next week we‚Äôll explore advanced visualization techniques including small multiples, animation, and specialized chart types. Consider: - How could animation enhance your stories? - What patterns emerge when you create multiple views? - Which stories need more sophisticated techniques?







Pro Tip



Start with the insight, not the data. What‚Äôs the one key message you want readers to remember? Build your story around that.








Important Dates




Lab 5 Due: Friday, 11:59 PM
Office Hours: Tuesday, 4:00-5:00 PM
Next Week: Advanced Visualization Techniques

title: Week 9: Final Project Workshop & Advanced Topics
text: This week we‚Äôll work on final projects and explore advanced topics based on class interests. We‚Äôll cover emerging trends in data visualization, specialized techniques, and provide dedicated time for project development and consultation.

title: Week 9: Final Project Workshop & Advanced Topics
text: This week we‚Äôll work on final projects and explore advanced topics based on class interests. We‚Äôll cover emerging trends in data visualization, specialized techniques, and provide dedicated time for project development and consultation.

title: Week 9: Final Project Workshop & Advanced Topics
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Apply advanced visualization techniques to final projects
Evaluate emerging trends and technologies in data visualization
Receive and incorporate feedback on work-in-progress
Plan and execute a comprehensive visualization project
Troubleshoot complex visualization challenges

title: Week 9: Final Project Workshop & Advanced Topics
text:
Workshop Format

Tuesday: Advanced Topics Seminar
üìä Emerging Trends in Data Visualization
Topics covered (student choice): - 3D visualization and virtual reality - Machine learning for visualization - Real-time and streaming data visualization - Collaborative and social visualization - Domain-specific visualization (scientific, business, etc.)


Thursday: Project Workshop
Individual consultations and group work time - 15-minute individual meetings with instructor - Peer collaboration and feedback - Technical troubleshooting - Design critique sessions

title: Week 9: Final Project Workshop & Advanced Topics
text:
Final Project Requirements

Final Project

Comprehensive Data Visualization Project

Components

Technical Implementation (40%)

Multiple linked visualizations
Appropriate use of interactivity
Clean, well-documented code
Professional deployment/presentation

Design & Communication (30%)

Clear narrative and insights
Effective visual design
Accessibility compliance
User-centered design

Process Documentation (20%)

Design iteration and rationale
Data source documentation
Technical challenges and solutions
User testing and feedback incorporation

Presentation (10%)

8-minute final presentation
Clear communication of insights
Demonstration of technical features
Q&A handling




Deliverables

Project Proposal: Due this week (1-2 pages)
Progress Check: Week 10 Tuesday
Final Presentation: Week 10 Thursday
Complete Project: Due Friday of Week 10

title: Week 9: Final Project Workshop & Advanced Topics
text:
Readings

Required

Student choice from advanced topic resources
Peer review of project proposals



Optional

The Future of Data Visualization
Visualization Research Papers - Browse recent conference proceedings

title: Week 9: Final Project Workshop & Advanced Topics
text:
Resources

Project Development

GitHub Pages - Free hosting for projects
Observable - Interactive notebook platform
Streamlit Community Cloud - App deployment



Advanced Libraries

D3.js - Advanced web-based visualizations
Three.js - 3D graphics
Deck.gl - Large-scale data visualization



Inspiration

Information is Beautiful Awards
Kantar Information is Beautiful
Visual Capitalist

title: Week 9: Final Project Workshop & Advanced Topics
text:
Individual Consultation Topics
Come prepared to discuss: - Project scope and feasibility - Technical implementation challenges - Design decisions and alternatives - Data sources and preprocessing needs - Timeline and milestones







Pro Tip



Use this week to get unstuck on any technical challenges. Don‚Äôt wait until the last minute to ask for help with complex implementations.








Important Dates




Project Proposal: Due Friday, 11:59 PM
Individual Consultations: Thursday (sign up for slot)
Progress Check: Next Tuesday
Final Presentations: Next Thursday
Final Projects Due: Next Friday, 11:59 PM

title: Week 6: Advanced Visualization Techniques
text: This week we‚Äôll explore advanced visualization techniques including small multiples, animation, network diagrams, and geographic visualizations. We‚Äôll learn when and how to use these sophisticated approaches effectively.

title: Week 6: Advanced Visualization Techniques
text: This week we‚Äôll explore advanced visualization techniques including small multiples, animation, network diagrams, and geographic visualizations. We‚Äôll learn when and how to use these sophisticated approaches effectively.

title: Week 6: Advanced Visualization Techniques
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Create small multiples and faceted visualizations
Design effective animated visualizations
Build network and tree diagrams
Create geographic visualizations and maps
Choose advanced techniques appropriately for your data and audience

title: Week 6: Advanced Visualization Techniques
text:
Lecture Slides
üìä Advanced Visualization Techniques
Topics covered: - Small multiples and faceting strategies - Animation principles and timing - Network visualization layouts and aesthetics - Geographic data and map projections - When to use advanced techniques

title: Week 6: Advanced Visualization Techniques
text:
Readings

Required

Tufte, E. (2001). The Visual Display of Quantitative Information, Chapter 4: ‚ÄúSmall Multiples‚Äù
Wilke, C. (2019). Chapter 21: Multi-panel Figures



Optional

Animation in Data Visualization - Best practices
Observable Animation Examples - Interactive examples

title: Week 6: Advanced Visualization Techniques
text:
Lab

Lab 6

Advanced Techniques Workshop
In this lab, you will: - Create small multiples with consistent scales - Build an animated visualization showing change over time - Design a network diagram or geographic visualization - Compare static vs.¬†animated approaches - Optimize performance for complex visualizations
üìò Lab 6 Notebook | Lab 6 Instructions
Due: Friday at 11:59 PM

title: Week 6: Advanced Visualization Techniques
text:
Resources

Small Multiples

ggplot2 Faceting
Matplotlib Subplots
Plotly Subplots



Animation

Matplotlib Animation
gganimate - Grammar of animated graphics
Plotly Animation



Geographic & Network

Folium - Interactive maps
NetworkX - Network analysis and visualization
leaflet for R - Interactive maps

title: Week 6: Advanced Visualization Techniques
text:
Looking Ahead
Next week we‚Äôll focus on data ethics and responsible visualization practices. Reflect on: - How can advanced techniques mislead audiences? - What responsibilities do we have as visualization creators? - When does sophistication become counterproductive?







Pro Tip



Advanced doesn‚Äôt always mean better. Use sophisticated techniques only when they genuinely improve understanding or reveal important patterns.








Important Dates




Lab 6 Due: Friday, 11:59 PM
Office Hours: Tuesday, 4:00-5:00 PM
Next Week: Data Ethics & Responsible Visualization

title: Week 4: Interactive Visualizations
text: This week we‚Äôll learn how to create interactive visualizations that allow users to explore data dynamically. We‚Äôll cover tooltips, filtering, brushing, and building interactive dashboards.

title: Week 4: Interactive Visualizations
text: This week we‚Äôll learn how to create interactive visualizations that allow users to explore data dynamically. We‚Äôll cover tooltips, filtering, brushing, and building interactive dashboards.

title: Week 4: Interactive Visualizations
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this week, you will be able to:

Create interactive plots with tooltips and hover effects
Implement filtering and selection mechanisms
Build linked visualizations and brushing interactions
Design effective interactive dashboards
Choose appropriate levels of interactivity for different audiences

title: Week 4: Interactive Visualizations
text:
Lecture Slides
üìä Interactive Visualizations
Topics covered: - Principles of interactive design - Types of interactions: select, explore, reconfigure, connect - Building interactive plots with Plotly - Dashboard design with Streamlit and Shiny - User experience considerations

title: Week 4: Interactive Visualizations
text:
Readings

Required

Shneiderman, B. (1996). ‚ÄúThe Eyes Have It: A Task by Data Type Taxonomy‚Äù (excerpt)
Interactive Data Visualization for the Web - Chapter 1 (optional background)



Optional

Plotly Dash User Guide
Streamlit Documentation

title: Week 4: Interactive Visualizations
text:
Lab

Lab 4

Building Interactive Dashboards
In this lab, you will: - Create interactive plots with Plotly - Build a multi-panel dashboard - Implement user controls and filters - Test usability with different user scenarios - Deploy your dashboard online
üìò Lab 4 Notebook | Lab 4 Instructions
Due: Friday at 11:59 PM

title: Week 4: Interactive Visualizations
text:
Resources

Python Tools

Plotly Python Documentation
Streamlit Gallery
Panel User Guide



R Tools

Shiny Tutorial
plotly for R
flexdashboard



Deployment

Streamlit Community Cloud
Shiny Apps

title: Week 4: Interactive Visualizations
text:
Looking Ahead
Next week we‚Äôll focus on storytelling with data and creating narrative visualizations. Think about: - What stories are hidden in your interactive visualizations? - How can you guide users through discoveries? - What insights emerge from exploration?







Pro Tip



Keep interactions simple and intuitive. Users should be able to understand what they can do within 10 seconds of seeing your visualization.








Important Dates




Lab 4 Due: Friday, 11:59 PM
Office Hours: Tuesday, 4:00-5:00 PM
Next Week: Storytelling with Data

Assessment



Component
Weight

Case studies

Midterm Project
30%
Week 6


Final Project
50%
Week 10




Case studies
Short weekly assignments that reinforce lecture concepts and develop technical skills. Emphasis will be placed on the in-class contribution to case discussion.


Midterm Project
Individual project focusing on exploratory data analysis and static visualizations.


Final Project
Group project (2-3 students) creating an interactive dashboard or data story on a topic of your choice.


Peer Reviews
Constructive feedback on classmates‚Äô visualizations to develop critical evaluation skills.

Create your visualization journal
